15. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already written, that were popular in visiting or social life before prohibition. You can make up your own rules.

The dance was always popular in our school until about 1916 when there were too much drinking and musicians charged too much.

The summer school theme died out about 1926.

The gymnasium opened about 1928-1930.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS: The Red Cross started in 1914 and won the war.

16. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? The Red Cross.

Give the date and reason for it being organized. The Red Cross.

17. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Yes.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. 1918-1920

Poor crops and hard times.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Most of the farmers joined up.

How many women belonged to it?

Women who could go.

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Concerned drawing and playing community sporting debates.

PICKNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 

Give year and month if possible. 1906 July and August.

26. Who organized it? 

Jack Anderson's father.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

It was for the entire community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 

Yes.

If not, do you know the dates of the first one that had been held? 1909

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

Golf, tug-of-war, 3 leg races, women always won.

Foot races, ball games.

30. What arrangements were made for seating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? 

There was a table on ground and sat in groups. No lunch was served.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

Sandwiches and coffee.

Pickle shark.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

Before dinner lasted an hour or more.
Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

There was nothing outstanding that year.

Describe any different kinds of games which you knew of in the early days, such as the larger community games, games at Sunday School, school, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in methods attending, activities, food and drink, when held.

We had only two games where there was a big crowd in a large field where we had a field day every year until about 1932 when people moved away.

What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

The picnics were all about the same. Baseball games for the larger gatherings were held at a nearby field or the schoolhouse. We made our own lemonade and sandwiches. The games were local boys' ball teams.

Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people). The boys were local boys' ball teams.

For what games was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? About 1914

How long did it continue? Until the present time
